titleStmt.title: Childhood Harran
SHAWI Corpus
titleStmt.funder: Funded by the FWF Austrian Science Fund under the number P 33574

publicationStmt.distributor: Austrian Center for Digital Humanities and Cultural Heritage

monogr.title: A Digital Dictionary of Shawi Arabic

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.
Private URIs using the rend prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a rendition element in VICAV rendition library.
Private URIs using the assets prefix are pointers to the location of the SHAWI media assets.

spanGrp.span: In former times, we used to have a lot of guests in my parents’ house. Many Turks and Syrians used to come and my parents’ house was always full.

When one (was looking for) a chance to sweep the floor… because of the people there was not any. (When) I wanted to do it, let’s say, (it was impossible) because one (of the guests) was sleeping and another sitting around. My father used to work in the governmental department, since he was (working) at the court.

Those who came would ask him or take information from him. My mother was very (hospitable), I mean she was open-handed and her face was like… I mean she was not a grumpy woman and did not annoy people so that they would not come to her.
The people loved her and my parents’ house was always full. Once I wanted… my parents had a lot of work; we had animals, we had cattle tied up, two cows, two cows.
They needed, let’s say, feeding, clearing the dung out, they needed to be milked. I had a brother, I had a brother who was paralysed and who needed someone to look after him at home.
After (my brother) Ibrāhīm one was born who was paralysed. His name was Ḥasan and he had lived for eighteen years until he passed away. He died when Fatḥiyye was born.
He needed someone to look after him; he could neither speak nor talk and he would defecate himself. He needed food, he needed like that; he basically needed someone to look after him.

My heart was with studying. I wanted to study at school and I also wanted to read the Quran, but they did not allow me. My father let me study for five years and then said, “Don’t go anymore, enough!”

At that time, all my friends were going to middle school, but he did not allow me. I wanted to study on. My heart was with studying! I really wanted to study and so (I said) that, if I can’t go to school, I at least want to learn to read the Koran.

Once, when I wanted to go, they did not let me. Tsk! I wanted to run away. I was the youngest at home, I was the youngest of four girls, but I was on a par with them: How could I prevail against them?

Like our (daughter) Faṭōš now. With my tongue. It is said that the one who has a (nimble) tongue is the victress among the women. Who has a (nimble) tongue is the victress among the women. At that time I brought the Quran because of my eloquence (lit. with my tongue) and I hid it here behind in my belt. Yes, I hid it here behind my belt, like that.
I used to wear a vest, I did not wear Arab clothes; I used to wear something like this dress here and a sweater, like that. I hid the Quran and went to a house in our neighbourhood.

There was the house of our neighbours and there was that girl who was crippled and who used to teach us the Quran. She gathered us all under a tree. (She did it only) for her parent’s salvation. She did not teach us for money, but she also wanted some favour from us.

She wanted from us… (She said), “Come let’s wash the dishes, let’s sweep the rooms, let’s wash the rooms, let’s finish my parents’ housework!” The crippled girl said to us, “Then, sister, I will teach you the Quran.”

And we… as for me I gladly went and helped the girl, because I just wanted to read the Quran. And when I came back home, they would say, “You went away again. Did you go to read (the Quran)?” Then they would start to grab me, one of them grabs me from my hair, another one pulls me by my sweater. My sisters!

They really treated me badly (lit. they inflicted torture on me), yes! One day my aunt came to us, my father’s sister, she is my father’s sister from his father’s side (i.e., his halfsister). She came to us, she visited us.
She came and said, “Look at her, her height has become...” Because I was really young but I was tall. Young, but tall. I had quite a height.

They grabbed me and said, “Why is she still wearing this thing, a vest? Why don’t you dress up like the Arabs? Why don’t you wear a traditional woman’s dress, a loose dress? Look how tall she is! She has already become a woman!”
They started to tear that sweater on me. She and my sister. My sister was very annoyed with me, because I did not work at home and just wanted to study.

They tore the sweater on me. They tore it, so I could not wear it again. So they could dress me in a cloak. But I did not want to wear the cloak and found myself another sweater and did not wear the cloak.

Now I sticked on going to the mosque; sometimes I went to the mosque for learning, sometimes I learned in the neighbourhood. One day my mother came to the late (neighbour); she is now dead, her name was Baḥriyye, the mother of the girl who was teaching us the Quran.
The mother of the teacher came to my mother. As she and we were neighbours, she visited to my mother and one day she said to me, “Come!” At home, before we would start reading the Quran.

The woman said to me, “Come! Look I have these aubergines! Come so we can hollow them out!” I got up and brought the thingy for coring, the corer. I mean what you can hollow out with. Then I cored the aubergines for them.

She was watching me and I did not break a single aubergine. I hollowed out almost twenty aubergines for her, for that woman, our neighbour, the mother of the teacher, the mother of the girl who was teaching us the Quran.
When she came to my mother, my mother was complaining about me saying, “Do you see this one? May God shorten her life! She goes to the teacher,
she is learning the Quran with a wise teacher, but she dissappears and does not work at home. She does not do anything and does not know how to do anything either.”

She said, “Why, my sister? And how she knows something! Wow, yesterday she came to us and was hollowing out these aubergines for me. Better than any old woman can do it! How (can you say) she does not know it?”

Aha, when I came back home, they grabbed me again (saying), “You are going for coring aubergines at... at Baḥriyye’s? Just to learn the Qurān?” They did not let me (go again). I wanted to learn, but they did not let me go.

Until I grew up. Then I started to study at home, but I did not know (how). Let’s say, when I got married, I came here then. First it was my parents and now it is my family… First it was my parents who did not allow me, and now it is my family.

I have got children; Ğamīle was in my arms – (saying to her husband) No, not you, but your family! – I am so afraid of the gossip (when my mother-in-law would say), “Look, sister, how she has left her work and went away for learning the Quran.”

I do not like it (that people) are talking about me behind my back (lit. words which follow me). Absolutely, since I have been born into this world, I don’t like it when (people) talk about me behind my back; that someone is talking about me.

I went again and I did not make it. We have brought this issue up, because only now we said, “How could this happen?” I mean, for twenty-one years, and before that… (Totally) for thirty years. Thirty years long (I wanted to learn), but I still have not got to study the Quran.

That means that the Lord of the Worlds has something (in mind); there is some wisdom behind it, there is wisdom, there is wisdom. But even if I want to, it did not grasp it (lit. it does not enter my mind). Once I wished to have ten children but only now when my brain is entering its fourties, only now I started to become aware of it.

How often did I go (to study) before! This, because my mind was only with the Quran. I just went and came back (without any results). But now when I started to go, thank God, I have finished (to learn) the art of reciting the Quran within six or seven months.

I have learnt all the suras within six or seven months, I mean, my brain has recently started to work (lit. to step in). I have recently started to fear (God) and so I started to... I mean, this began to have an influence on me. Enjoy it!
